description: Dive into "Chiang Mai's Picture-Perfect Paradises" — a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Chiang Mai's Picture-Perfect Paradises

places.generalDescription: Wat Phra Singh Woramahawihan is a revered 14th-century Buddhist temple located in Chiang Mai, Thailand. It is home to gold and copper Buddhas, ancient manuscripts, and intricate murals. The temple's main attraction is the Phra Phutta Sihing Buddha statue, which holds great cultural significance and is paraded through the city during the Songkran Festival.

sources.snippet: Wat Phra Singh: Nestled within the heart of the old city, Wat Phra Singh is a stunning example of Lanna-style architecture. Established in the 14th century, the temple is home to an ancient Buddha statue known as Phra Singh (Lion Buddha), which is believed to have been brought to Chiang Mai from Sri Lanka. As you stroll through the temple grounds, be sure to admire the intricate woodcarvings and murals that adorn the buildings, and take a moment to pause and reflect in the serene atmosphere.
sources.shortName: Chiang Mai: The Ultimate Travel Guide (2024)

sources.snippet: Ratchadamnoen & Singharat.The crowning glory of downtown Chiang Mai and one of the most popular wats in town. Although tourists crowd the lanes around the temple during the day, wake up early and you will likely be the only traveler on the streets watching the monks file out of the temple for dawn alms. (There is a cute coffee shop just across the street to the left, Shong Cafe, very sweet owner!)
sources.shortName: 23 Secret Spots I Love in Chiang Mai (2023)

sources.snippet: Another one of Chiang Mai’s Old City gems is Wat Phra Singh, located in the western part of the city. Enter the gorgeous temple complex and be ready to photograph some of the loveliest Thai architecture you’ve ever seen. From the ornate designs of the golden plating on the exterior to the gorgeous slant of the temple’s pointed roof, there’s no shortage of photo opportunities here.
sources.shortName: An Instagrammer’s Guide to Chiang Mai – Passion Passport

sources.snippet: The city’s old town, surrounded by ancient walls and moats, is a treasure trove of traditional Lanna architecture, bustling markets, and serene temples like the iconic Wat Phra Singh and Wat Chedi Luang. Each corner of the city tells a story, making it perfect for street and architectural photography.
sources.siteName: Palm Villa Luxury Pool Villa Resort Chiang Mai
sources.shortName: Photographing Chiang Mai: Best Spots for Capturing Memorable Shots
13 Best Photo Spots in Chiang Mai You Don't Want to Miss

sources.snippet: Wat Phra Singh, located in Chiang Mai, Thailand, is a revered Buddhist temple known for its stunning architecture and religious significance. Dating back to the 14th century, the temple houses the sacred Phra Singh Buddha image.
sources.shortName: 25 Places to Visit in Chiang Mai, Tourist Places & Attractions

places.name: Wat Phra Singh Woramahawihan

reviews.text:
A large temple that has a friendly atmosphere. There a few smaller temples to view as well. A large golden tower is a unique attraction to the location, apparently known as a Pagoda, as told by a local. There is a small group of markets outside selling various things.
There are also some very lifelike monk statues.

Beautiful complex of temples situated at walking distance from the Chang Mai centre.
It has some temples dedicated to  monks as well as the classics Buddhist temple.
I appreciate in particular the golden "stupas" situated at the back of the main temple.
Worth a visit if you are around!

Highly recommend visiting this temple. Inside, there are a few shrines where you can take off your shoes and step inside to look around or worship the gods, which feels very spiritual. This is one of the best temples I've visited during my time in Chiang Mai.

places.address: 2 Samlarn Rd, Tambon Si Phum, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Nestled atop a lush, forested hill on the outskirts of Chiang Mai lies Wat Phra That Doi Kham, also known as the Golden Temple. This hidden gem is celebrated for its magnificent 17-meter seated Buddha statue, which gleams in white and gold. With roots tracing back over a millennium, this temple offers visitors an enchanting experience filled with intricate shrines and pagodas to explore amidst the serene backdrop of the Doi Suthep Mountain range.

sources.snippet: Sunset at Wat Phra That Doi Kham: End your day by watching the sun go down at Wat Phra That Doi Kham, also known as the Temple of the Golden Mountain. The golden hues of the setting sun against the temple’s golden chedi create a magical backdrop for your photos.
sources.shortName: Most Famous Spots (Private And All-Inclusive)

places.name: วัดพระธาตุดอยคำ

reviews.text:
Chiang Mai has many Temples in its old town, as well scattered around in the mountains. I suggest visiting this one, which is in the western mountains, reachable within half an hour drive from downtown.
It's a magnificent Temple with many Buddha statues - sitting, standing and reclining. Besides, it offers great city views beneath you from the viewing terrace

Short, beautiful hike with an impressive temple at the top! We are traveling in May so it was HOT and fair warning that the temple is extra hot. Not a ton of shade, and the sun bakes the white tiles which reflect back to you. Definitely be prepared with water, electrolytes, sunscreen, and a hat. A portable fan wouldn't hurt either.

If you want to hike to the top, you have to get dropped off at the parking lot/market across from Cup Fine Day. Keep in mind that it is more than just the dragon stair case you'll have to climb. There's about 300 steps through the forest and the staircase itself is about 180. There's a sign that says it's 1.5 kilometers, but that seemed like too much. It's really quite short, but it's steep.

If you're not up for the hike but still want to take the dragon stairs, you'll have to get dropped off at the top of the temple and then walk down the stairs to walk up them. There's not car drop-off zone at the bottom of the staircase.

If you can, we definitely recommend the whole hike :) the forest is beautiful and you'll see some cool animals. We saw a peacock!!

Very beautiful Wat. It was a very hot day so we drove up. They have some very impressive statues. There are side shops that sell some things. Bathrooms are traditional no paper down the toilet type and were fairly clean when I used them.

places.address: Mae Hia, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50100, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Wat Phra That Doi Suthep, a revered temple in Northern Thailand, is known for its gold stupa, pagodas, and museum. Perched on a mountainside, the temple offers stunning panoramic views of the city. To explore off-the-beaten-path routes in the region, consider hiring a local trekking guide through a reputable company. This allows access to non-touristic areas and an authentic experience.

sources.snippet: The Buddhist Wat Phra That Doi Suthep, built in the early nineteenth century, is one of Chiang Mai's most revered and important temples. The building is a stunning example of architecture and great craftsmanship. Wat Phra That Doi Suthep temple offers you an incredible experience full of serenity and calm, with a museum tour and souvenir shop.
sources.shortName: 25 Places to Visit in Chiang Mai, Tourist Places & Attractions

sources.snippet: Sunrise at Doi Suthep Temple: Start your day by witnessing the breathtaking sunrise over Chiang Mai from the iconic Doi Suthep Temple. The soft golden light and panoramic views make it the perfect spot for Instagram-worthy photos.
sources.shortName: Most Famous Spots (Private And All-Inclusive)
13 Best Photo Spots in Chiang Mai You Don't Want to Miss
Chiang Mai Pictures - Chiang Mai Travel Photos

places.name: Wat Phra That Doi Suthep

reviews.text: Beautiful temple. Even though it is a bit far from Chiang Mai city center, it is definitely worth visiting. There is an elevator to take you to the top from the parking, but there are also stairs which are super short, so both options are equally convenient. There is a market at the bottom close to parking, with a huge choice of souvenirs and clothes is. Since drivers usually refuse to go that far, the best deal is to arrange with them to drive you and wait there to take you back.

Great experience. Beautiful views. Gorgeous icons. So lovely. Free entry. Cold beverages are sold as are simple souvenirs.

You get to see a gorgeous temple that's not very far outside of Chiang Mai. You can take a Grab here -- you'll want to book it round trip to save yourself the hassle of the drive back.

Have an umbrella on hand to shade you from the sun. It's intense and there are areas with no shade where you are walking.

Summary: Beautiful, peaceful, well maintained, easily accessible from the city

It wasn't too busy when I visited. It is low tourist season now (June).
Must wear temple appropriate clothing (cover knees and shoulders) you must take off your shoes before entering the main part of the temple. You can take pictures inside, no problem.

Temple/ Wat: Stunning architecture, painting and attention to detail. It felt very peaceful within the temple, lots of people were praying or meditating and paying respects.

The Park/Grounds: The grounds surrounding were well maintained.
Good clean facilities.
Lots of view points to take photos.
Many souvenir shops and some restaurants/ food stalls at the entrance.

Steps: There are a set of steps that take about 5 minutes to ascend (steep but slow walking) to the start of the temple, if you are not able to do, you can take a cable car/ lift.

Transport: I booked a grab from the city centre and he messaged us to ask if we wanted him to wait for us and drive us back. So it's easy to negotiate a full trip price, most grab/ bolt drivers are happy to do that.
There were many Tuk Tuk and Song Thaews available once you're up there to take you back too. Some people drive motorbikes up which has a great view but I would only recommend if you were experienced as the road is very windy and quite steep. It's also rainy season and rained whilst we were there so could make the road slippery.

places.address: Tambon Su Thep, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Nestled just outside the bustling gates of Chiang Mai's old city, Wat Lok Moli is a captivating Buddhist temple that dates back to at least the 1300s. Unlike most temples that face east, this unique site aligns along a north-south axis, adding to its charm. The highlight here is its striking chedi, one of the tallest in the area, which houses the ashes of several kings from the Mengrai dynasty.

sources.snippet: Another stunning Lanna temple in Chiang Mai is Wat Lok Moli. Both Viharn and the nearby big chedi are popular locations for photographers visiting Chiang Mai.It is right next to Wat Rajamontean, and like Wat Rajamontean, it is not too crowded. These two sights are easily complementary to one another.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Instagrammable Places In Chiang Mai
13 Best Photo Spots in Chiang Mai You Don't Want to Miss

places.name: Wat Lok Moli

reviews.text:
Quiet and peaceful temple.
The architecture is beautiful and it feels like a trip to ancient times.
Feels sacred and serene.
You can just sit inside the temple for a while to calm the mind down.
We visited this temple which was near our hotel. There is an old stupa at the back of the shrine hall. It is lit up at night and looks nice. The shrine hall was peaceful and quiet.

This was Absolutely Beautiful and loved the art and architecture of everything. The size and mass of some things are so impressive. Such a great stop on the temple quest and must be added to your go to list for temples.

Feels very spiritual and i highly recommend!

places.address: 298/1 Manee Nopparat Rd, ตำบล ศรีภูมิ อำเภอ เมืองเชียงใหม่, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Tha Phae Gate, a well-preserved city gate with a rich history dating back to the Lanna Kingdom, was originally known as Chiang Ruak Gate. Situated by the Mae Ping River, it served as a vital entrance for trade routes. The gate's name was changed to Tha Phae, meaning 'Harbor of the Floating House,' reflecting its connection to river traders and fishermen. Today, it stands as an iconic landmark within the ancient city wall of Chiang Mai.

sources.shortName: Chiang Mai Pictures - Chiang Mai Travel Photos

places.name: Tha Phae Gate

reviews.text: Always interesting seeing older history related things like the Tha Phae Gate. Definitely a touristy spot but still worth a visit. Very popular spot for pigeon photos and my girlfriend really wanted to do that, so stopped by. Not too many people on a Monday afternoon so we were quickly able to take photos then leave.

We visited early morning around 6 am, and literally no other tourists were around. But when we finished taking pictures, a group of local tourists came.
Lots of pigeons, like hundreds of them. You can feed them if you want.
I recommend going here early in the morning, just after the sunrise is best.

We were lucky when we visited as they had a community tourism festival with many vendors. Overall it's basically a square where a lot of tourists visit along with pigeons!! There are many stores close by and it's walkable. Not a lot going on when the festival isn't in action but worth the visit anyway!

places.address: Tha Phae Road, Chang Khlan Sub-district, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Wat Chedi Luang Varaviharn is a captivating temple complex nestled in the heart of Chiang Mai's Old City. This historical site features a partially crumbled chedi dating back to the 15th century, which stands as a testament to the city's rich cultural heritage. Visitors are drawn not only by its architectural grandeur but also by the pillar believed to offer protection to the city.

sources.snippet: Wat Chedi Luang: Located within the old city walls, Wat Chedi Luang is a majestic temple complex that dates back to the 14th century. The temple’s towering brick chedi, which was once the tallest structure in Chiang Mai, was partially destroyed by an earthquake in the 16th century but still stands as an impressive testament to the city’s architectural heritage. In addition to exploring the temple grounds, visitors can participate in a “Monk Chat” session, where you can engage in conversation with the resident monks and learn about their lives and beliefs.
sources.shortName: Chiang Mai: The Ultimate Travel Guide (2024)

sources.snippet: Founded in the mid-1300s, Wat Chedi Luang is perhaps the most dramatic temple in Chiang Mai due to its ruined brick and stone stupa that still stands impressively high. The accompanying temple is a place for quiet reflection or ogling the decadent architecture. Try approaching the temple from eccentric angles or during the early morning to frame the stupa in a striking golden light.
sources.shortName: An Instagrammer’s Guide to Chiang Mai – Passion Passport

sources.snippet: The city’s old town, surrounded by ancient walls and moats, is a treasure trove of traditional Lanna architecture, bustling markets, and serene temples like the iconic Wat Phra Singh and Wat Chedi Luang. Each corner of the city tells a story, making it perfect for street and architectural photography.
sources.siteName: Palm Villa Luxury Pool Villa Resort Chiang Mai
sources.shortName: Photographing Chiang Mai: Best Spots for Capturing Memorable Shots
13 Best Photo Spots in Chiang Mai You Don't Want to Miss

sources.snippet: Get your driver to park in front of the main temple building for a photo. Then head behind to photograph the tuktuk in front of the chedi as well. Doing this you are creating more interesting photos of both tuk-tuk and temple.
sources.shortName: The Best Chiang Mai Photo Location Tips

sources.snippet: Corner of Phra Pok Klao & Ratchamanka.Another popular wat (and for good reason) it’s pretty and quiet and likely nearby any of the popular guesthouses and eating spots you pick in town!
sources.shortName: 23 Secret Spots I Love in Chiang Mai (2023)
Chiang Mai Pictures - Chiang Mai Travel Photos

places.name: Watchediluang Varaviharn

reviews.text: It is an ancient and important royal temple in Chiang Mai, featuring magnificent and beautiful architecture. The site is grand, impressive, peaceful, spacious, and clean. There is parking available within the temple grounds. Entry is free for Thai nationals, while foreigners are charged an entrance fee of 50 baht per person, with tickets available for purchase at the entrance.

Glad I picked this temple over the rest, the main hall is both grand and serene, with few fans to cool you down, one could sit in the middle of the hall and feel the calming presence as the monks are chanting.

Walk to the rear and you can see the old temple remains, as well as some other small religious buildings. 50baht for entrance ticket.

Beautiful Buddhist temple in the heart of walled Chiang Mai. 50 baht to enter. Although in the tourist area, going in here was calming and peaceful, as it should be. The temple and surrounding shrines are wonderfully decorated  and time should be taken to enjoy the area.

places.address: 103 Prapokklao Road, Tambon Si Phum, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Chiang Mai's historic old town, Wat Chiang Man stands as a testament to the city's rich heritage, being its oldest temple dating back to the late 13th century. This enchanting site features a stunning gold chedi and an array of impressive elephant statues that showcase remarkable craftsmanship. Visitors are drawn not only by the ancient pagoda but also by the serene library known as Ubosot, which serves as a vital space for ceremonies.

sources.snippet: Wat Chiang Man, located in the heart of Chiang Mai, is the oldest temple in the city, dating back to 1296. This sacred site holds immense historical and cultural significance, featuring intricate Lanna-style architecture and ancient relics.
sources.shortName: 25 Places to Visit in Chiang Mai, Tourist Places & Attractions
13 Best Photo Spots in Chiang Mai You Don't Want to Miss

places.name: Wat Chiang Man

reviews.text: A large temple complex that is pretty serene and a good place to ponder and relax.  Its not as popular as other temples inside the city center but Wat Chiang Man has its own charm and worth the stop especially in the late afternoon where you can relax in the shade in the area.

A serene temple. Been living in town for almost a year and I had just set foot in this temple. It's not a huge complex, but so quiet, well-maintained, and charming. I saw some photos taken during winter when flowers were still blooming, this place looked definitely charming. I went here during summer in May, still a great experience to just have a reflection and chill time for a while

This Wat with its tunnel, fish feeding and Ashoka pillar grabbed my interest instantly. Each moment there was like I was building a connection with the place. Peace, greenery and quiet worship.
One thing I noticed, all the Buddha statues are similar. Peacefully serene and calmly meditative.

places.address: 171 Ratchapakhinai Rd, Tambon Si Phum, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Chiang Mai, Royal Park Rajapruek is a breathtaking botanical garden that invites visitors to immerse themselves in nature's splendor. Spanning approximately 200 acres, this expansive park features meticulously landscaped grounds adorned with over 1,900 species of plants and flowers. Each themed zone showcases unique aspects of Thai culture and horticulture, including the enchanting Thai Tropical Garden and the vibrant Orchid Garden.

sources.shortName: Top 10 Instagrammable Places In Chiang Mai

places.name: Royal Park Rajapruek

reviews.text:
This place weirdly feels as if it could qualify as being off the beaten track given how few people were here on a beautiful day.
A lovely large park and a really beautiful Orchid Garden and air conditioned rose garden. Very peaceful. Make sure you allow at least half a day here. The restaurant in the Park serves very good Northern Thai food and has a good story.
Well worth the time. Not far from the center of Chiang Mai. Excellent value for money

Large botanical garden with many areas that you can explore for a full day. You can rent a bicycle or use a shuttle bus to access each zone in the area. Recommend this for the winter season with beautiful flowers.

Located a short distance from Chiang Mai city, this Park is well worth a visit. A beautiful park with 80 hectares of different gardens to explore. The free shuttle bus service is useful for moving between gardens. Shuttle bus leaves every 15-20 minutes - convenient for using the shuttle to move between gardens. Plan on being here for at least 3 hours. The Skywalk is good for seeing the Park from above the ground - there's a ramp up, as well as stairs. Wheelchair friendly - there was wheelchairs to hire at the ticket selling area. We didn't see the whole Park on our visit, and will come back again to see the parts we missed.
There is plenty of parking - take the ticket you're given to the ticket selling booth and have it stamped/validated for free parking.
Entry is ฿200 for foreigners - well worth it.
There's 1 small cafe selling drinks and snacks. There is a restaurant - we didn't go there.

places.address: 334, Mae Hia, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50100, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Angkaew Reservoir, situated within Chiang Mai University, is a charming park offering a serene walking and jogging path, along with benches and grassy areas perfect for picnics. The park provides an ideal location overlooking the reservoir, where visitors can enjoy leisurely strolls through various pathways adorned with captivating water ponds and lush green spaces. With leafy trees providing shade and ample sitting places, it's a delightful spot to unwind.

sources.snippet: Ok, you don’t have to go jogging, although it is a very popular place for runners. But if you want to escape the hustle and bustle of the city, you can have a stroll around Angkaew Reservoir. Located within the Chiang Mai University campus, this picturesque and tranquil spot serves as a popular recreational area for students, locals, and tourists.
sources.shortName: A Local's Guide to Chiang Mai: Hidden Gems and Popular Spots

places.name: Angkaew Reservoir

reviews.text: This is a great place to enjoy your morning or evening exercise or just enjoy the setting. Beautiful saroundings and the mountains in the background made this my go to place a few times when visiting the city. Coffee shops also available.

Came here 3-4 times during my trip. Really enjoy the golden hours and sunset time here. Chill and relaxing vibe. Absolutely the best place to walk and enjoy the nature. In the summer, i would recommend coming here around 6-7p.m to avoid the summer heat

Beautiful area around Chiang Mai University, perfect for a leisurely run along the reservoir. Not crowded at all. It's clean and relaxing being near the water and all the greenery. Highly recommended to check it out if you're in CM!

places.address: RX42+JPM, Sukhothai 5 Alley, Tambon Su Thep, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Wua Lai Walking Street is a vibrant outdoor bazaar that spans about a mile and takes place every Saturday evening on Wualai Road near the Silver Temple. It offers an array of traditional street snacks, handmade crafts, souvenirs, and local delicacies. The market is known for its bustling atmosphere and diverse offerings including handcrafted lamps, dolls, soaps, jewelry, clothes, original paintings, and locally designed jewelry.

sources.snippet: Another exciting entry on the list of the best places to visit in Chiang Mai, Saturday Street Walking Market is best known for its bustling traditional bazaar scene with huge variety of products being sold at cheap prices. It doesn't matter whether you are a foodie, shopaholic, or somebody seeking a fun filled evening in Chiang Mai, Wui Lai Market, that turns into a street walking market on Saturdays is a spot loved by locals and tourists alike.
sources.shortName: 25 Places to Visit in Chiang Mai, Tourist Places & Attractions

places.name: Wua Lai Walking Street Saturday Market

reviews.text: Great Saturday market. Lots of food to choose from. Loads of souvenir choices. Enjoyed seeing the artists at work. So much original stuff that I haven't seen at other markets in SE Asia. Pretty busy but still easy to walk around without bumping into other people. We got a hair stick, bbq sausage (not my favorite), bbq chicken & mochi (bit different than Japanese mochi), mango & passionfruit smoothie & kimchi pancakes (delicious).

The walking street is a mix of everything! There are lots of food options, and some carts also provide seating (there are specific tables/chairs belonging to stalls so it's best to ask them to find you seats if you wish to order from them). We ordered bbq squid from the stall and could also eat some other food at the table (they were very nice and didn't ask us otherwise). We saw some people looking for a seat, so we finished ours quickly and offered it to them.

You can have a full meal at this place, tom yum soups or noodles, meat skewers, bbq seafood, juices, cakes, sushi, toasts etc. I recommend that you could walk around and buy food as you go, and eventually find a stall that has seating so that you can sit comfortably to enjoy them all. Do be gracious and not hold up the table if there are others waiting, so that the stallholders can have more turnover.

After filling your stomachs, walk around to purchase souvenirs, clothing etc there are many!
More enjoyable than the Sunday market as it isn't as busy. Loads of fun and loads of options to buy gifts, souvenirs, food etc. We came when there were some live performances which was great to see.

places.address: 69 Wua Lai Rd, Haiya Sub-district, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50100, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Baan Kang Wat is a charming artisan village situated in the Hand Dong District, just 5km south of downtown Chiang Mai. The village hosts a delightful artists market every Sunday from 8.00am to 1.00pm, showcasing the work of local creatives. This eco-village comprises standalone buildings housing galleries, restaurants, cafes, and workshops for art, design, yoga, and meditation.

sources.snippet: Baan Kang Wat Artist Village: A little out of the city, this artist village is a hub of creativity. With its unique architecture and artisan shops, it offers a different view of Chiang Mai’s culture.
sources.siteName: Palm Villa Luxury Pool Villa Resort Chiang Mai
sources.shortName: Photographing Chiang Mai: Best Spots for Capturing Memorable Shots

places.name: Baan Kang Wat

reviews.text:
This is a charming little art village with lots of unique handmade items and creative goods.

Though the space isn't very big, it's full of character perfect for a relaxed afternoon walk.

You'll find some truly special pieces here, and it's also a great spot for taking aesthetic photos.
Highly recommend stopping by if you're nearby. You might just find something you love!🌹

Amazing and cool spot in Chiang Mai. I love how it brings together so many handcrafted pieces and shops in one place.

It's fun to look around, shop, and even join activities like pottery, painting, or making your own journals. The place is also great for walking around, taking pictures, and just enjoying the creative vibe.

They have food and drinks too, so even if you don't join the activities, it's still worth a visit for a stroll and a bite. Definitely a must-visit place.

My recent visit to Baan Kang Wat was truly impressive, offering a vibrant atmosphere perfect for those seeking unique handmade goods.

The market boasts an abundance of diverse stalls, from intricate jewelry to gourmet treats. Every turn reveals artisans showcasing their passion, inviting hours of browsing, discovering unique gems, and engaging with creators.

Despite its bustle, Baan Kang Wat is commendably well-shaded, with awnings and trees ensuring a comfortable visit, even on sunny days. This allows for leisurely exploration without the heat.

Beyond the crafts, Baan Kang Wat is incredibly photogenic. Its charming layout, colorful displays, and unique elements offer abundant photo opportunities, from detailed crafts to bustling scenes, all enhanced by beautiful natural light.

More than just a shopping destination, Baan Kang Wat offers a delightful experience. Its diverse stalls, comfortable shade, and visual appeal make it a must-visit for unique finds and a memorable outing.

places.address: 191-197 ซอย วัดอุโมงค์, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Doi Suthep is a 5,499-foot mountain in Chiang Mai, Thailand, known for its picturesque trails through evergreen forests and a hilltop temple called Wat Phra That Doi Suthep. The temple, coated in gold and nearly 800 years old, offers stunning views of the city below. It's a popular tourist spot, so visiting in the morning is recommended to avoid crowds.

sources.snippet: Songthaews leave from the CM Zoo on Huay Kaew.High on the nearest hillside, Wat Doi Suthep has a brilliant gold shining Chedi and expansive views of the sprawling city of Chiang Mai, Thailand. Great for sunrise photographers or anyone in search of early-morning solitude then the Doi Suthep temple is ideal. On a general note, before jumping into the major sections, since so much of my life revolves around internet—and yours might too!
sources.shortName: 23 Secret Spots I Love in Chiang Mai (2023)

sources.snippet: Chiang Mai’s Doi Suthep temple is a symbol of the city — and a beautiful place to photograph. Start at the 306 steps that lead up to the temple and capture the intricate mosaic dragons that flank the stairway. Once at the top, capture the almost comical amount of discarded shoes (visitors must explore the temple barefoot), beautiful flowering trees, and intricate tile work.
sources.shortName: An Instagrammer’s Guide to Chiang Mai – Passion Passport

sources.snippet: Wat Phra That Doi Suthep: Perched on a mountaintop overlooking the city, Wat Phra That Doi Suthep is Chiang Mai’s most famous temple. Established in the 14th century, this sacred site is renowned for its golden chedi (stupa) and stunning panoramic views. To reach the temple, you can either climb the 306-step Naga staircase or take a cable car.
sources.shortName: Chiang Mai: The Ultimate Travel Guide (2024)

places.name: Doi Suthep

reviews.text: About a half hour enjoyable scooter ride to this must visit temple just outside of the city. Very well maintained and you get great views of the area.

Nice temple about 30 minutes away from Chiang Mai. We took a red car to get there. It was pretty busy but that didn't take away from the experience. We spent around 1 hour walking around the temple. After we got some food over the road.

A temple situated outside of Chiang Mai city is a sacred site nestled within a forest, attracting devotees for prayer. To reach the temple, visitors must ascend over 300 stairs or opt for the elevator by purchasing a 20 THB ticket. The entry fee for foreign visitors is 50 THB. From Chiang Mai, transportation options include Bolt, Grab bike, or cab. Alternatively, a shared ride can be availed from the songthaew stand near Chang Phuak Market for 80 THB.

places.address: Suthep, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Doi Suthep-Pui National Park is a forested sanctuary in Chiang Mai Province, Thailand, known for its natural beauty and cultural landmarks. The park encompasses two mountains, Doi Suthep and Doi Pui, and is home to the revered Wat Phra That Doi Suthep temple. Visitors can climb 309 steps to reach the temple complex and enjoy panoramic views of Chiang Mai.

sources.snippet: This national park is really a grab bag of great Instagram photo settings. The most famous, perhaps, is the Doi Suthep Temple. You can’t leave Thailand without getting a picture here.
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots In Chiang Mai

sources.snippet: Doi Suthep-Pui National Park: Home to the famous Wat Phra That Doi Suthep Temple, this park also offers panoramic views of Chiang Mai city, especially beautiful at sunrise or sunset.
sources.siteName: Palm Villa Luxury Pool Villa Resort Chiang Mai
sources.shortName: Photographing Chiang Mai: Best Spots for Capturing Memorable Shots

places.name: Doi Suthep-Pui National Park

reviews.text:
The Yi Peng Lantern Festival originated from the Lanna culture in Northern Thailand. The meaning of this festival is for people to express their respect to the gods and pray for good luck and prosperity in life.
The Lantern Festival originated from the Lanna belief that if you worship the Buddha's relics during the full moon of the 12th lunar month, you will receive blessings. However, the Buddha's relics are said to be kept in the highest level of heaven, so the Lanna people lit lanterns and released them into the sky to send their wishes.
Beautiful golden temple on the top of the mountain in Chiang Mai . It's easy to go there. You can grab the red local bus or rent the scooter on your own. Try to go in the morning to avoid the crowds.
Absolutely beautiful, well worth the drive, for me it was worth it to rent my own car so I could stop and go to as many places as I wanted.

places.address: RW48+RC4, Sriwichai Alley, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Chiang Mai, Chom Cafe and Restaurant offers a delightful fusion of Thai and international cuisine in a charming setting. The restaurant's inviting ambiance and delectable dishes have made it a popular choice for both locals and visitors seeking an unforgettable dining experience.

sources.snippet: | Location: 2 13 ม.2 Somphot Chiang Mai 700 Pi Rd, Mae Hia, เมือง Chiang Mai 50100, Thailand ( Google Maps). | Hours: Daily 11:00 ~ 22:00. ❥ 陳͟͞甯͟͞🌸(@_ning_c)님의 공유 게시물님, 2019 8월 23 3:55오전 PDT
sources.shortName: 7 Most Instagram-Worthy Cafes in Chiang Mai

places.name: Chom Cafe and Restaurant

reviews.text:
I'm so grateful I found out about this place that looks like a painting 🖼️ on IG!

This is my second time in Chang mai & first time coming here!

The reservation process (messaging on IG or 📱) was easy, our table perfect outdoor (ask for outdoor) the sounds of the water & the scene 🎬 & service & the food so yummy! 😋  I recommend come about an hour before sunset!

We paid around $50 for 3 so good! Highly recommend

This is a nice place. Tasty food and very relaxed and fresh atmosphere. The portions are quite generous. We spent around 1,700 for 2 starters to share, 3 main dishes, 3 drinks and one dessert to share. I would definitely recommend 😀

Of course! Here's a natural-sounding review in English that you could post on Google Maps:

---

Rating: ★★☆☆☆ (2.5/5)
The place is quite small but charming-perfect for lunch or dinner. I went there for dessert and ordered a sweet dish along with coconut juice. Unfortunately, the taste didn't impress me much; it was just average. Overall, I'd give it 2.5 out of 5.

places.address: 2, 13 ม.2 Somphot Chiang Mai 700 Pi Rd, Mae Hia, เมือง, Chiang Mai 50100, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Cafe Arte is a charming cafe located in Chiang Mai, Thailand. It offers a perfect ambiance and atmosphere, making it an ideal place to meet with friends in a lovely setting. The cafe is housed inside an air-conditioned European-style building on a spacious corner lot, providing a nostalgic and relaxing atmosphere. Visitors can enjoy amazing coffee, hot or cold beverages, specialty desserts, and sandwiches. One of the favorite beverages at Cafe Arte is the Dirty Coffee.

sources.snippet: | Location: 155/4 หมู่ 2 ถ.เจ็ดยอด-อยู่เย็น ซ.8 เมือง Chiang Mai 50300, Thailand ( Google Maps). | Hours: Friday to Wednesday 9:00 ~ 17:00 (Closed on Thursdays). freesia_jeehee(@freesia_jeehee)님의 공유 게시물
sources.shortName: 7 Most Instagram-Worthy Cafes in Chiang Mai

places.name: Cafe Arte

reviews.text: A great spot to enjoy a coffee, set in a beautiful old building with charming, well-maintained grounds, with many visitors stopping to take photos of the lovely surroundings. The barista was super friendly and welcoming, adding a personal touch to the overall excellent experience.

This café truly lives up to its artsy name - a serene, Zen-like haven.

The spacious garden is peaceful and airy, and the indoor space is filled with beautiful displays and decor.

The coffee is excellent, and the girl who took our order had the kind of bright, genuine smile that lit up the whole place and made it feel even more welcoming.

Note: Although the café is large, it's not intended as a co-working space. Guests with laptops or iPads are allowed to use the Wi-Fi for only one hour.

So come here to read, sip coffee, and simply enjoy the moment with your friends or loved ones.

PS: There's a laundromat, a supermarket, and other handy spots nearby -
so if you're looking to grab a great cup of coffee while waiting for your laundry, this place is a perfect choice.

We'll definitely be coming back - again and again.

This is one of the most stunning cafes I've ever visited-not only was the food and drink delicious and full of flavour, but the staff were incredibly kind and even customised a dish to make it vegetarian for me!

places.address: 155/4 หมู่ 2 ถ.เจ็ดยอด-อยู่เย็น ซ.8, เมือง, Chiang Mai 50300, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Wat Suan Dok, also known as the "Field of Flowers Temple," is a tranquil Buddhist temple located about 1 km west of Chiang Mai's old city. The temple was established in the late 14th century on the grounds of a former royal flower garden. One of its most striking features is the impressive 48-meter-high bell-shaped chedi that enshrines sacred relics from Sukhothai.

sources.snippet: Suthep Road, just before Nimmanhaemin.Definitely located on any tourist map in town, explore the pretty white structures and temples before enjoying lunch at Pun Pun, an organic café at the far back of the temple complex. One of the most gilded temples I’ve visited, Wat Doi Suthep glistens gold in Chiang Mai’s bright sunshine.
sources.shortName: 23 Secret Spots I Love in Chiang Mai (2023)

places.name: Wat Suan Dok

reviews.text: Beautiful area to visit where you can have coffee and snacks from shop nearby. Some parts are under renovation. Entering temple has 20 THB entrance fee but other areas are free to explore. Worth a visit for royal relics area alone. Lots of parking space and wasn't crowded during daytime on Sunday.

Very nice temple with stupas
Monk chat available with monks in particular Phra KK managing the meditation retreats for many years. He speaks fluently English. Highly recommended

Very impressive temple. Definitely worth visiting. word of warning all the white surfaces will really reflect the Sun which can be blinding if you are photosensitive But on the other hand, this also makes for spectacular photos in the middle of the day.

This is a temple so remember to wear respectful clothing, you must have a shirt. Your shoulders shouldn't be showing and ideally your knees shouldn't be showing either.

places.address: 139 Suthep Rd, Tambon Su Thep, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand

sources.snippet: After stuffing yourself with delicious food, you might want to walk it off. Just a few minutes away you can find another lovely spot in Chiang Mai. It’s not one of the Chiang Mai hidden gems, but it also not a place where tourists flock.
sources.shortName: A Local's Guide to Chiang Mai: Hidden Gems and Popular Spots

places.name: Mae Kha Canal

reviews.text: It was a leisurely afternoon 🌥️. There were many traditional Chiang Mai handicrafts 🌈 and a little girl singing 🎶 , which was very cute 🥰 . It is recommended to go after 16:00 so that it will not be too hot 🥵😅.

Mae Kha Canal – A Charming Hidden Gem in Chiang Mai

Mae Kha Canal is a must-visit spot for those exploring Chiang Mai. Though small in size, it offers a picturesque setting that's perfect for photo shoots and vlogs. The canal is lined with local vendors selling beautiful handmade crafts, Thai street food, and even Chiang Mai's own craft beer. One of its most delightful surprises? The many friendly cats that lounge around the area, adding a cozy, local charm to your visit.

This is basically a tourist place with a few stalls selling food, arts and crafts.
The view was quite beautiful because of the lights on the bridges. The ambience was nice, but sometimes it's crowded with groups of tourists. Come earlier to avoid too many tourists.

places.address: 9 Sridonchai Rd, Haiya Sub-district, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50100, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Huai Kaeo Waterfall is a seasonal attraction located near Chiang Mai, offering smaller cascades and plenty of hiking trails. The area features picturesque natural scenery with easy access to the waterfall, although it may not be wheelchair or stroller accessible past a certain point. Visitors can enjoy the serene pools below the falls for picnicking and relaxation, as well as embark on an interesting jungle hike starting from the waterfall area.

sources.snippet: The list of the most exquisite natural tourist places in Chiang Rai is incomplete without a mention of this piece of nature’s art – Huay Kaew Waterfall. Located in close proximity to Chiang Mai Zoo, this waterfall offers perfect space and atmosphere for rejuvenation and recreation.
sources.shortName: 25 Places to Visit in Chiang Mai, Tourist Places & Attractions

places.name: Huay Keaw Waterfall

reviews.text: This Space is a must-visit for a peaceful nature escape. Open 8 am to 5 pm, it's immaculately clean, free to enter, and blissfully uncrowded. The abundance of butterflies and old trees is enchanting, and the seating near the waterfall offers a truly meditative experience. Highly recommended.

Huay Kaew Waterfall is a lovely little nature escape right at the edge of Chiang Mai city, located within Doi Suthep–Pui National Park. It's very easy to reach, just a short distance from the Chiang Mai Zoo and the Kruba Srivichai Monument, making it a convenient stop for both locals and travelers. The area is green, peaceful, and perfect for relaxing or enjoying a picnic. You can rent a mat, sit by the flowing water, and just enjoy the cool breeze from the forest.

Even though it's not the largest or most dramatic waterfall in Chiang Mai, it has its own charm. In the dry season, the water flow can be quite low, but during and after the rainy season (July–November) the stream becomes stronger and more refreshing. It's a popular spot for families, couples, and solo visitors who want a quick break from the city without having to hike far. There's also a short trail leading to Wang Bua Ban viewpoint for those who want a bit of adventure.

Overall, Huay Kaew Waterfall is not just a scenic natural spot-it's a peaceful retreat that's free to visit, easy to access, and well worth including in your Chiang Mai itinerary.

Absolute must visit. The hike was enjoyable. Water was cold. Though you'll only find water as yoh go up higher and not at the entrance (I visited in March first week).
Its relatively deserted in the morning and people crowd up later from afternoon tk evening. I continued to hike upwards to try to see the source of waterfall. I found several plunge pools on my way. However i couldn't go beyond a certain point. Surely recommend a hike upwards, if you're interested, although quite challenging.

places.address: Suthep, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50300, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Wat Rajamontean, also known as the Dragon Temple, is a stunning 15th-century structure located in Si Phum, Chiang Mai. The temple boasts impressive maroon and gold spires and is guarded by playful dragon statues at the entrance. Inside, visitors can admire a large seated Buddha and several ornate Chakravartin Buddhas adorned in gold. This peaceful and colorful temple offers a serene atmosphere for meditation and prayer, away from the crowds of tourists.

sources.snippet: It’s not a traditional Thai temple, and it has unique characteristics. Wat Rajamontean is small and can be seen in 30 minutes, but don’t miss the huge Buddha and the interior.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Instagrammable Places In Chiang Mai
13 Best Photo Spots in Chiang Mai You Don't Want to Miss

places.name: Wat Rajamontean

reviews.text: In my opinion this is a top 5 temple in Chiang Mai to go see. Beautiful decoration, very well kept temple and temple area and no aggressive dogs at all. The big Buddha statue is magnificent and the color scheme of this temple is just fantastic. Very easy to access and find. Definitely a must go to temple in Chiang Mai
It's a little gem at Old City. I was attracted by the outdoor Buddha statue and beautiful stairs from the entrance to the temple. 1 min away from across the street is another temple Wat Lok Moli.

Loved the colors of this temple and the size of the outside. The insides aren't as big and the temple isn't the same. as the one across the street. this is still worth a stop on your temple quest .

Good for women and men i did not see any restrictions for women. also remember to take your shoes off 🙏🏽

places.address: 149, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand

places.generalDescription: Chiang Mai Gate is a bustling area known for its vibrant markets and lively atmosphere. The Wua Lai (Saturday) Market, located opposite the gate, offers a wide array of goods to browse and bargain for every Saturday from 4 pm onwards. Nearby, the renowned Silver Temple, Wat Sri Suphan, showcases intricate decorative elements that shimmer in the late afternoon light.

sources.snippet: The South Gate of the city, right on the inside moat road are scattered stalls.This is a hotspot for local street food eats—that means cheap. Vegetarian eats run about 35 baht here—under 60 baht for a meaty dish. There’s a good hodgepodge of locals and tourists here and it’s a great place to sample a bit of everything Chiang Mai has to offer.
sources.shortName: 23 Secret Spots I Love in Chiang Mai (2023)

places.name: Chiang Mai Gate

reviews.text: Well preserved. Many sections along the river, part of the great scenery of the city.

Went to the Sunday Night Walking Market. Fantastic! A must do if you come to Chiang Mai.... featured on Saturday night, too. Mostly food, some clothing and other stuff.  I bought a great pair of elephant pants. :)
Amazing place with such a rich history. A must see if you come to Chiang Mai :)

places.address: QXJQ+GJW, Mun Mueang Rd, Tambon Phra Sing, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand

sources.shortName: 13 Best Photo Spots in Chiang Mai You Don't Want to Miss

places.name: Wat Saen Mueang Ma Luang (Wat Hua Khuang)

reviews.text: Absolute gem of temple. Great architecture and in almost pristine condition. Best thing is the tranquillity of the place. Excellent place to calm your soul. I almost didn't want to rate the place to keep it away from the crowd but it's too good not to share

This is one of the most beautiful temples in Chiang Mai. Like other reviewers mention, the structures are well kept and every detail built and drawn on the structures are very amazing and beautiful. You can observe the details without being annoyed by other tourists since there is no tourist 😃

Wat Saen Muang Ma Luang, also known as Wat Hua Khwuang, is a hidden gem in Chiang Mai that combines Burmese and traditional Thai (Lanna) architectural elements. The temple features a striking main viharn (hall) with a multi-tiered roof, adorned with decorative naga (serpent) balustrades and intricate golden carvings. The red entrance doors depict the Hindu god Indra, adding a unique cultural touch. Visitors are greeted by lifelike elephant statues and large black elephant sculptures, lending a distinct character to the entrance.

One of the most notable structures is the ancient brick chedi, which has a weathered appearance, enhancing the temple's historical ambiance. Although some buildings are newer, the complex maintains traditional designs, such as the richly decorated windows featuring zodiac animals. Within the peaceful garden areas, there are also three ornate bell towers (ho rakangs), and the grounds are adorned with colorful murals and statues.

This temple is a tranquil retreat from the more crowded tourist spots, making it a must-see for those interested in Chiang Mai's spiritual and architectural heritage.

places.address: 175 Prapokklao Road, Tambon Si Phum, Mueang Chiang Mai District, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand
